Protocols

Protocols define methods for special functionality. Protocols only describe the methods a type must offer to support this functionality. Types can conform to protocols by implementing all methods and declaring the conformation.

Defining a protocol defines a type. All types that agree to that protocol are compatible to this type.

Declaration

The syntax to define a protocol is simliar to the way of defining a class:

protocol âŸ¶ ğŸŠ type-identifier protocol-body
protocol-body âŸ¶ protocol-method | protocol-method protocol-body
protocol-method âŸ¶ [documentation-comment] [âš ï¸] ğŸ– emoji-id arguments return-type

For example:

ğŸŠ ğŸ’¿ ğŸ‡
  â—ï¸ğŸ¶
ğŸ‰

Here we declared a protocol named ğŸ’¿. All classes that conform to this protocol will have to implement the method ğŸ¶. This protocol doesnâ€™t tell us anything about the actual type but we do know that all types that conform to ğŸ’¿ are capable of playing music and therefore must provide the ğŸ¶ method.

You can use the â—ï¸ to require instance methods inside the ğŸŠ body. At present it is not possible to require initializers or type methods.

Conforming

To make a class conform to a protocol you must declare that it conforms to the protocol using the conformance syntax:

protocol-conformance âŸ¶ ğŸŠ type

Let us declare a class that conforms to ğŸ’¿.

ğŸ‡ ğŸ“± ğŸ‡
  ğŸŠ ğŸ’¿

  â—ï¸ ğŸ¶ ğŸ‡
    ğŸ˜€ ğŸ”¤LalalalağŸ”¤â—ï¸
  ğŸ‰
ğŸ‰

The actual statement to achieve this is ğŸŠ protocolName, where protocolName must be the type name of the protocol, and can occur everywhere in the class body.

Promises also apply when implementing protocol methods. An extension can also make a class conform to a protocol.

Calling Methods on Values of Protocol Type

Methods on protocol values are called like any other methods:

ğŸ–ğŸ†• cd_like ğŸ’¿
ğŸ†•ğŸ“±ğŸ†•  â¡ï¸ ğŸ– cd_like
ğŸ¶ cd_like

Multiprotocols

It might happen that youâ€™ll need to deal with values of types that implement several protocols. For instance, you might want to provide a method which requires an argument that can be accessed with ğŸ½ï¸ and can be compared as defined by the ğŸ’¿ protocol. This is where multiprotocols are of service.

You can use a multiprotocol type like so:

ğŸ± ğŸ½ï¸ğŸšğŸ”¡ ğŸ’¿ ğŸ±

For instance, when declaring the arguments to a method:

â—ï¸ ğŸŒˆ a ğŸ± ğŸ½ï¸ğŸšğŸ”¡ ğŸ’¿ ğŸ± ğŸ‡
  ğŸ’­ ...
ğŸ‰

As expected, a can now be used both as an instance of a type conforming to ğŸ½ï¸ğŸšğŸ”¡ and as an insatnce of a type conforming to ğŸ’¿.
